tests.name: Philosophy
tests.description: Find out how you stand along many philosophical dichotomies from egoism and altruism to skepticism and absolutism.
tests.preamble: You will be asked a number of questions. These will be in the form of either a statement or a scenario. For each of these questions you should state whether you agree or disagree (broadly speaking). Please try to answer as honestly as possible.
tests.instruction: How much do you agree/disagree with the following statement?

questions.text: I would rather find true love than be wealthy.
I would rather be given an expensive car than save the life of a starving child.
I would rather receive money than gifts.
I would rather be in a sexual relationship without intimacy than be in an intimate relationship without sex.
There is no inherent meaning to life.
A world without colour is far darker than a world without order.
Society will always need a strong authority.
I believe in some form of spiritual afterlife.
If I had to choose: I would save myself instead of a loved one.
The ends usually justify the means.
I would rather live a life of personal pleasure than settle down and have children.
Life is suffering and fundamentally meaningless.
When making a decision the underlying reasoning is always more important than the consequences.
Extraordinary claims require extraordinary evidence.
There is more to the world than mere material.
Most people are inherently selfish.
We should strive towards a utopian society.
Sometimes we must suffer in the present so that we can have a better future.
No actions are inherently moral or immoral.
Reason is more important than emotion.
It is foolish to believe a claim if there is no evidence to back it up.
My mental well-being is more important to me than material possessions.
Selflessness is a virtue.
Our society is fundamentally flawed and in need of radical reform.
I prefer friendships that help me grow as a person as opposed to ones that are exciting.
There is an underlying morality in everything that we do.
Without music, life would be a mistake.
There exists an omniscient, omnipotent and absolute being.
Consciousness is immaterial.
My own prosperity matters more to me than the happiness of those around me.
People who desire constant success must change their conduct with the times.
It is virtuous to live a simple life without an abundance of physical comforts.
We are all insignificant in the eyes of the universe.
A society without marriage would be better than a society without divorce.
Our society defines us.
Spirit and matter are two separate entities.
I will usually put my family, my community or my people above my own personal goals.
Revolution is sometimes a benefit to society.
People have the right to try to achieve as much pleasure as possible.
Life is despair.
Educating the mind without educating the heart is no education at all.
Human beings possess free will.
It is good to strive towards fame, wealth and power.
I would rather live alone in luxury than in poverty with friends and family.
Societal progression should be carried out slowly and in small, incremental steps.
Pleasure is the highest good.
I don't care about morality.
It is foolish to let emotions influence your decisions.
Nothing can be proven to be true.
A life of fame and fortune is more desirable to me than a happy and meaningful life.
Be kind, for everyone you meet is fighting a hard battle.
The world of ideas is superior to the physical world.
It is better to live a frugal life.
Moral statements are statements of truth or fact more than they are statements of emotion or desire.
Scientific research is more important than art and music.
I would rather live in a wealthy society with little to no morals than live in a poor society with morals and identity.
We should focus on the well-being of our community.
Our ideas stem from reality.
Our primary pursuit should be our own passions and pleasures.
There is a distinction between 'good' and 'bad' that goes beyond mere human nature.
The primary goal of humanity is the pursuit of knowledge
Human beings possess a soul.
Individuals should always act in their own self-interest.
Each person has a function in society.
There is a way to live that is morally ideal.
It is not wise to be affected by strong passions and fears.
The universe obeys natural and fundamental laws.
People cannot be truly altruistic.
Lofty ideals such as justice and liberty are of great importance to me.
Authority must always be ridiculed.
Without faith in a God we cannot be content.
Emotion cannot be discounted when making decisions.
We can never perceive true reality.
We should help those who are struggling in our society.

tests.name: Economics
tests.description: How do you think the economy should be run? Find out now and see your results displayed along multiple economic axes.
tests.preamble: You will be asked a number of questions. These will be in the form of either a statement or a scenario. For each of these questions you should state whether you agree or disagree (broadly speaking). Please try to answer as honestly as possible.
tests.instruction: How much do you agree/disagree with the following statement?

questions.text: The freer the market, the freer the people.
Self-sufficiency is vital for any economy.
The government continuing to intervene in the economy will eventually lead to tyranny.
Providing national basic income is a realistic and desirable goal.
There should be little to no industrialisation in the economy.
The state should initiate price controls on various goods.
A progressive income tax is good for the economy.
Strong tariffs are necessary in a sovereign state.
A country should be self-sufficient when it comes to providing basic needs such as food and water
Economic intervention is needed in order to ensure income equality.
National work programmes which ensure employment are practical and feasible.
The economy should be based around agriculture and natural resources.
Long term, multi-year plans are important initiatives for the state economy.
Luxury goods should be highly taxed.
Goods produced within the country should receive subsidies to help them out-compete foreign goods.
There should exist self-sufficient local cooperatives within the economy.
The state should have the ability to harshly punish negative forces in the economy.
Nationalised education and health care systems are of great importance in a strong society.
Our economic order should be directly linked to ecology.
It is best if the state's economic policies are flexible and can be changed to suit the current situation.
Corporate taxes should be increased.
The issuing of national patents is good for the economy.
It is damaging to the economy to be reliant on foreign countries.
The state has no right to interfere in the private affairs of individuals.
Railways and other transport systems should be nationalised.
Nations are better off having an organic economy that is tied to nature.
State intervention in the economy almost always results in catastrophe.
Tax cuts are necessary in order to maintain a prosperous economy.
Trade restrictions and import taxes are good.
Small-scale, free initiatives should be promoted within the country.
A planned economy is best.
It is better to have a nationalised banking system.
An economy should be founded on competition and consumption.
The bigger the government the better.
Aside from funding necessary public programmes (the police force, etc) taxation should be as limited as possible.
Trade distorting policies don't work.
It is better if the state receives significant support from foreign countries and corporations.
It is better if private businesses are left to their own devices.
Multinational corporations are more efficient than publicly-funded systems.
Economies need to industrialise and modernise in order to flourish.
A functioning economy will always need to have a complex set of rules and guidelines kept in place.
Higher income households should be expected to pay a higher income tax.
Unregulated access to foreign markets is a good thing.
Economic powers such as the EU should provide support to struggling countries.
Every intervention in the economy is a potential threat to individual liberty.
Foreign businesses should be encouraged to reside wherever they like.
An economy that utilises foraging techniques, such as hunting and gathering, is preferable.
The economy should be organised organically, devoid of planning and rules.
We should increase taxes so that we can fund better social systems.
Trade should be heavily regulated.
Ideally, states should depend on and support each other.
Statist dreams of utopia are one of the biggest threats to economic prosperity.
We're better off with a modern, globalised economy.
Monetary value or currency is at the core of any functioning economy.
An economic structure should be fluid, lacking in formalisation, paperwork and rules.
All citizens should pay taxes at the same rate.
Overall, protectionism has had a net negative effect on economies.
Economies should support each other and promote inter-dependence.
The economy should obey the state; never the other way around.
Globalisation is inevitable and for the better.
We should promote commercial lifestyles of profit and usury.
Strong public administration is needed in order to uphold the law, maximise efficiency and prevent favoritism.
Taxpayers shouldn't be expected to fund expensive social systems.
The government should have major control over the economic ins and outs of the country.
For an economy to function the state needs to have significant control over it.
We should strive towards a universal, global economy.
Bureaucracy is needed so that law, order and a functioning economy can be maintained.
Specialised teams should run different aspects of the economy as opposed to a single bureaucratic body.

tests.name: Literature
tests.description: Do you prefer realistic literature or fantasy? Dark or light-hearted? This test breaks down your literary taste into seven different dichotomies!
tests.preamble: You will be asked a number of questions. These will be in the form of either a statement or a scenario. For each of these questions you should state whether you agree or disagree (broadly speaking). Please try to answer as honestly as possible.
tests.instruction: How much do you agree/disagree with the following statement?

questions.text: I prefer prose that is direct and straight to the point.
It is better if a story maintains a solid and traditional structure with regard to pacing, characters, etc.
All great artists are philosophers first and foremost.
Literature allows us to live out our dreams.
I prefer stories that take on the world.
Art is most compelling when it's at its darkest.
I'm most interested in works that invert or play around with traditional literary structures.
I'm interested in stories that act as a gateway to another world.
I prefer authors who never use a long word when a short one will do.
Works that feature clear, archetypal representations of good and evil are preferable to more philosophical texts.
The most exciting questions relate to progress and technology in the modern world.
I prefer stories that are set in the real world as opposed to an imaginary one.
Literature with grandiose and dazzling prose is best.
Literature should be optimistic about the future.
I want the work I read to challenge me ideologically.
I appreciate it when an author clearly puts forward a moral doctrine in his or her work.
I'm most interested in stories that focus on the day-to-day lives of people.
I prefer stories that have a clear and direct style and aren't experimental in structure or prose.
I prefer it when the story takes centre stage as opposed to the author's style.
Stories are at their best when they are inspirational or hopeful.
The death of a beautiful woman is one of the most poetic topics in literature.
Traditional towns provide a better backdrop than modern metropolises when it comes to analysing human nature.
One of the primary purposes of literature should be to instill a love of life in the reader.
Authors should focus on telling direct stories before diving into profound questions.
Literature provides an ideal opportunity to promote healthy moral values.
A small number of characters and settings are preferable in a story.
I enjoy ironic and sarcastic literature.
Stories set in the modern technological world are more compelling than those set in the old traditional world.
I tend to prefer literature which is full of passion and life as opposed to literature that is nihilistic and dark.
It is vital that a story should espouse strong moral virtues.
Stories about ghouls and monsters often say a lot more about people than stories merely about humans.
Despair is at the center of all great art.
I gravitate towards literature that analyses the modern cosmopolitan world.
Literature that lacks a moral message isn't very literary at all.
I prefer authors who have unorthodox writing styles and are willing to experiment.
Individual lives are always more fascinating to examine than the grander picture.
I'd rather read to explore dangerous questions than to receive comfortable answers.
I prefer stories that feature a small and intimate cast of archetypal characters.
I'm interested in authors who use comic prose to accurately critique dogma.
Literature, in its purest form, is about escaping reality.
I prefer stories set in the countryside or in small communities.
I'd rather read stories that are comforting and attractive as opposed to challenging and harsh.
I enjoy literature that pulls moralism apart.
I find nature and the ecosystem more inspiring than the day-to-day lives of most people.
Literature is best when it's as coherent as possible and lacking in pretensions.
I prefer stories with a wide and cinematic scope.
I'm drawn to literature that represents life in a realistic and authentic way.
Works of great beauty are timeless and should be celebrated.
Most great works are set in major cities or global states.
I'm more intrigued by stories that are esoteric or cryptic.
I'm most interested in works that explore and advocate a coherent moral system.
Literature allows one to escape from the meaninglessness of individual life and explore humanity in a greater picture.
I'm drawn towards literature with a darker aesthetic.
Art should accurately represent life in its truest form.
I'm most attracted to literature that focuses on 'the simple life' and living in harmony with nature.
I enjoy reading authors who raise grand metaphysical and epistemological questions.
The greatest stories follow a clear, concise and rigid style.
I prefer authors with a refined and lavish style as opposed to a direct one.
I enjoy it when an author dabbles with the avant-garde.
Works that deal with the psychology of industrial society interest me more than those that deal with traditional and 'natural' societies.
I'd rather read stories that are devoid of challenging or controversial material.
Life is suffering and art should reflect this in a clear way.
I prefer imaginative or dreamlike literature.
One of the primary purposes of literature should be to lambast puritans and zealots.
In literature, village life is more compelling than city life.
There's enough magic and wonder in our own world - no need to imagine new ones.
It's not worth reading stories unless they raise profound existential questions.
Art is at its best when it's challenging the traditional order of its genre or field.
Literature is about growing old enough to read fairy tales again.
For a story to hold my attention it needs to have a solid structure and maintain archetypal consistency.

tests.name: Memes
tests.description: Do you like memes? /r/FellowKids here we come...
tests.preamble:
You may need to take the test in landscape mode if you are viewing the site on a mobile phone.
For each question you will be shown two memes. You should choose the meme you prefer and indicate the degree to which you prefer it.

Note: some users may find some of the images used in this test offensive; please bear this in mind if you are easily upset or offended.
tests.instruction: Choose which meme you prefer and to what degree you prefer it.

tests.name: Politics
tests.description: Do you lean to the left or to the right politically? This test will attempt to discover your philosophical beliefs regarding politics along a number of axes.
tests.preamble:
Unlike most online political quizzes this test will attempt to determine your basic political beliefs through philosophically-oriented questions - as opposed to questions directly related to policy.

You will be asked a number of questions. These will be in the form of either a statement or a scenario. For each of these questions you should state whether you agree or disagree (broadly speaking). Please try to answer as honestly as possible.
tests.instruction: How much do you agree/disagree with the following statement?

questions.text: Hierarchies will inevitably be formed in every society.
We are living in a post-modern age with no discernible 'true' reality.
A truly democratic system is unrealistic.
The penal system is designed to protect the interests of the ruling class.
We must retain the core constitutional principles of our institutions.
The traditions of law and justice in my community must be greatly respected.
We should not question sovereign authority so long as it provides peace.
A society that promotes equal outcomes for all is desirable.
The traditional family is the embodiment of an authoritarian personality and, ultimately, fascism.
There is no grand tradition of anything only various competing claims.
We have no transcendent purpose beyond our own material pleasure.
Collective obligations that are placed on an individual by society are inherently immoral.
Corruption and decay is an 'iron law' of human societies.
Humanity only experiences linear growth - not decay.
Societies develop through a cooperative social contract.
The concepts of 'good' and 'evil' are subjective.
The industrial revolution and its consequences have been largely negative.
People should be treated equally regardless of their social group.
Technological development has brought about a better world.
To ground any coherent worldview one needs higher spiritual values.
Religion is merely a distraction from the material world.
Language developed as a tool to dominate and exclude 'the other'.
Human society should be viewed through a pessimistic lens.
Societies of vulnerability will always defeat societies of exclusion.
A liberal democracy is the final stage in societal development.
There is more to this world than the purely physical.
All people possess a soul.
History can be understood as a great march of progress.
Human nature is nasty, brutish and short, it must be repressed by society.
We are defined morally, at least in part, by our actions.
If a society is not grounded by ancestral traditions it will fall into chaos.
We should strive to eliminate social biases toward minority groups.
Humanity can be relied on to self-regulate and self-reform.
We are currently in the dark age of human flourishing.
A collective founded on absolute values will always outlive those founded on relative values.
Without a constraining force society will always tend towards immorality.
It is better to die standing than to live on one's knees.
All institutions are biased towards their own cultural background.
No institution can be truly egalitarian.
Without God and higher ideals institutions will collapse.
Some people will always be more successful than others.
Our modern world is progressing towards a utopia.
Man's natural state is egalitarian and pacifistic.
We can best pursue meaning by living disciplined and virtuous lives.
Different combinations of social identities produce unique forms of disadvantage and oppression.
Science and rationality are best when it comes to describing our world.
There is more to life than the pursuit of pleasure.
Liberation of the individual from all arbitrary boundaries (race, gender, etc.) is ideal.
Social relations should be understood, primarily, as expressions of power.
Societies tend toward immorality and, as such, they require a strong leader to maintain order.
Society will always consist of rulers and subjects.
The ideas of progress and rationality are symptoms of societal decline.
Every civilization goes through a birth, a rise and a fall.
The most successful people are those who are the most deserving of their success.
Individuals have a duty towards upholding the collective good.
Societal hierarchies often come about through the oppression of disadvantaged groups.
Direct or pure democracy is the ideal form of government.
An action is generally good if its consequences are good.
Peaceful societies are rare and fragile.
Through sexual exploration and liberation we can escape the societies of control.
